headline: Mansfield Police Department awarded over $145K for body cameras
author: Lou Whitmire
sentences: With these grants, more than four dozen law enforcement agencies that have never had body cameras before will be able to invest in this technology to help protect their officers and offer transparency to the public."
"This is just the start of many new ways we'll be helping law enforcement with state-of-the-art tools and innovative programs to fight crime and protect the public," said DeWine in his news release.
Porch said the department can't give body cameras to every officer but with this third source of funding the department will have a total of 63 to 65 body cameras for the kiosk system.
Mike DeWine has awarded more than $4.7 million in grant funding to 109 local law enforcement agencies for expenses associated with launching or maintaining body-worn camera programs.
DeWine prioritized the creation of the new Ohio Body-Worn Camera Grant Program in the state's 2022-2023 operating budget, which was passed by the Ohio General Assembly last year.
Additional body-worn camera funding will also be offered as part of the $250 million that DeWine and the Ohio General Assembly dedicated to law enforcement in December.
In total, this funding will help agencies purchase around 1,700 new body cameras, as well as computer equipment, software, video storage and more, DeWine added.
On Tuesday, Porch said the $145,183.35 will be used to purchase more body cameras, along with infrastructure and personnel.
Of the 109 local law enforcement agencies receiving grants, 49 will use funding to create new body-worn camera programs.
The grant program totals $10 million over the biennium, with the remaining grants to be offered in fiscal year 2023.
The Mansfield Police Department will receive a grant for $145,183.35, according to DeWine's announcement on Monday.
DeWine said in a news release, "Body cameras have quickly become a necessary tool for modern policing.
On Dec. 6, Mansfield Police chief Keith Porch announced that MPD had begun using police body cameras.
Some non-sworn staff will be trained how to fulfill body camera footage requests to media and others.
The other 60 agencies will dedicate funding toward expanding or upgrading existing technology.
"We feel very fortunate to receive this funding," Porch said.
Costs come with storage of the videos.
